title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Why Communities?



Improving the Research Culture: COS Celebrates 10 Years




I’m probably preaching to the converted in saying that open research is a good thing but you may be wondering what role do communities have to play in open research?
This is pyramid diagram is from an article by Brian Nosek, one of the co-founders of the Center for Open Science and represents how to bring about culture and behaviour change.
Infrastructure is at the base of the pyramid of culture and behaviour change, you need tools such as the Open Science Framework which allows researchers to register their studies, share materials, data and output at any point to accelerate communication regardless of publication status.
But for this to be effective the user experience of using needs to be low friction to encourage adoption and many popular services integrate with each other and strive to make their tools accessible.
From the top of the pyramid is policy, from funders and institutions, which define what you have to do within the system to gain recognition.
This in term defines the incentives that reward participants for participating in the system.
Whilst individuals can always go about changing their own behaviour, this can be challenging when the culture is to maintain the status quo, not all colleagues are keen to change their working practices. But an effective way of supporting and nurturing individuals who are seeking to change is via a supportive community as seeing people undertaking new practices normalises the behavioural changes, provides support and demonstrates that open research is possible.
Thus communities serve to accelerate the adoption of change, in this case Open Research practices, and importantly can feed up the pyramid to the top to influence and shape policy as practices and guidelines develop and mature over time.


Nosek (2019) Strategy for Culture Change

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
What are Communities?

“a dynamic, social grouping where members align around a shared purpose (or multiple overlapping purposes) and participate in a shared culture. Active community participation frequently aligns with a sense of belonging and affiliation to the community. In a community the flow of information is multi-directional with members able to do something as a result of being connected to one another that they would not be able to do alone.”
Community: shared purpose, belonging, culture

I think before going further its worth giving a clear definition of what a community is and this quote from the Center for Scientific Collaboration and Community Engagement encapsulates it nicely…

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
What are Communities? (cont.)







Nurturing a community within Sheffield and as part of the wider International community…

Brings together people with shared goals.
Gives them a sense of belonging.
Allows people to make connections and network.
This gives them opportunities to learn and grow.

…all of which encourages and enables people to take action, normalising practices and driving the cultural shift to adopting Open Research and greater transparency. As a group this can bring about more change than any one individual acting on their own.


The Turing Way - Communities DOI : 10.5281/zenodo.3695300

text:
Open Science Tools



https://101innovations.wordpress.com/



As I’m sure most of you are aware, there are a lot of tools out there these days for undertaking open research, and this graphic shows just some of the tools available.
Services like Research Gate, PLOS One, F1000, pre-print servers, R, Python, BioConductor, Overleaf, Zotero, LaTeX, Git, GitHub and GitLab to name a few on this graphic. There are a lot out of different tools and services out there.
It’s therefore not surprising that some people are hesitant to change when presented with the mantra to adopt Open Research as it can be overwhelming.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Diffusion of Innovation


When any innovative technology or practice comes along you will typically encounter this sort of pattern of diffusion where there are a few innovators who develop the system, slightly more early adopters will pick things up soon after, and following them there is the early majority where uptake increases dramatically. Unfortunately there is still a large proportion of people with varying resilience, the late majority, and some with higher resilience, somewhat unflatteringly termed the laggards but that’s not meant to be disparaging.
By normalising open research practices through building an active community we can accelerate and lower the bar for adopting Open Research practices and reach the early and late majority and the stragglers faster.
And I don’t think its about making massive leaps, you don’t have to instantly become an expert in typeseeting LaTeX documents under version control which are compiled into documents and websites automatically and are available in real time. We learn best when we take small steps, one at a time.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Connecting People

Varying career stages
Range of skills/knowledge/experience.
Support beyond training courses.
Sharing knowledge between researchers to learn from each other.


When one person teaches, two people learn.

The University comprises a range of researchers in terms of career stages, early, mid and advanced and across each of these there is variation in the skills, knowledge and experience around the different areas of Open Science, some people have experience in pre-registering study protocols, others are familiar with the FAIR Principles for Data sharing and might have experience using University of Sheffields ORDA system.
Training courses are great for getting started but typically when applying what you’ve learned to your own work or situation there will be questions and problems that crop up and this is where the support of a community comes in really helpful as you have a network of people you can contact and ask for help.
Sharing this knowledge directly between researchers so they can learn from each other is a highly effective means of normalising the practices because…when one person teaches two people learn.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
The Power of Peer-to-Peer

Less intimidating
Experience > Expertise
Practical > Theoretical
Specificity
Participation is the key


Peer-to-peer teaching can be far less intimidating than formal teaching environments as it lowers the threshold for asking for help when it is felt that the community is supportive and encouraging.
Very often experience is more important than expertise. From my own experience knowing a system really well means that you can often overlook certain aspects that you take for granted and that someone new to a system might struggle to understand or use.
In a similar vein sharing practical experience of how to use tools is often more beneficial than deep theoretical explanations. There can often be many aspects that might be covered in theoretical material that aren’t relevant to someone getting started and only come into play further down the line.
Specificity is also important, if you’ve a highly specific question being able to ask someone in your or the wider community is much more likely to result in a relevant answer than having to trawl through a bunch of search results or long detailed documentation.
But the key to a successful community really is about participation though and peer-to-peer interactions help promote this.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Open Research Working Group
Open Research Conversations
Drop-in sessions
Sheffield Reproducibilitea
Sheffield R User Group . . . .
Your Ideas


 



There are already a number of community activities in Sheffield.
The Open Research Working Group convenes regularly to discuss and progress issues surrounding open research within the University and hold regular drop-in sessions to discuss aspects of Open Research.
Jenni Adams, the library Open Research Manager and organised or OpenFest2023, organises the monthly Open Research Conversations which are lunchtime seminars open where invited speakers give short talks on specific topics which are followed by discussion.
In the past Sheffield had Reproducibilitea Journal Clubs organised by Zuzzana Zagrodzka and Jim Uttley which afforded an opportunity to review and discuss different aspects of Open Research.
Similarly there used to be the Sheffield R User Group which met to share experiences of using the R statistical software ecosystem for undertaking reproducible research.
Both of these groups are being restarted so keep an eye out for announcements of events in October.
Most importantly though the community is shaped by you, if you’ve an interest or need to know more about a particualr subject please come and join the community. If you’ve material on Open Research practices, whether that is pre-registration, making your data Open and FAIR, reproducible writing, using the Open Science Framework or anything that you might have shared with colleagues within your team or department please consider sharing it with the wider community within the University.
The more people who participate the stronger and more supportive the community will be. And remember the community is self-guiding so its activities and direction are meant to be guided by its members so please consider get involved.
